metadata.title: Data Science on the Death Star. Improving life in the Empire, one DS… | by John Naujoks | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Data Science on the Death Star
metadata.description: Data science is not magic (of the Force for that matter). As someone with a real interest in the field, I have often been warned by others and read about the complicated world of adopting data…

all_paragraphs: Data science is not magic (of the Force for that matter). As someone with a real interest in the field, I have often been warned by others and read about the complicated world of adopting data science into an organization. There have been many stories that go like this: A place hires a data scientist because they are told it’s the cool thing to do, disappointment ensues because of lack of understanding, a data scientist needs a job again. There is obviously a disconnect sometimes of what the role can be.

My simple definition of the role would be this: a data scientist is there to analyze and interpret data to build business solutions. It is work that requires contextualization, problem framing, experiment design, and data collection to craft solutions that make things better. You are free to Google the countless Venn diagrams that might drill more into what skills and knowledge that entails, but it is essentially business understanding, statistics, and programming knowledge put in a blender on high.

I get questions from friends often about what data science can do, which is sometimes challenging as what it is can vary greatly by the context of what an organization does. If you are at Netflix, you could be working with big data to test algorithms for recommendations. If you are at eBay, you could be working on fraud monitoring tools for listings. If you work at Apple, you could be working on object recognition for photos that a user takes. Just as every business has different needs, so will their use and need for data science.
I am by no means an expert, but let’s think through an example and see what types of solutions come to mind:

They have great benefits, a good salary, and the travel is amazing. The Emperor has sent you right to headquarters, The Death Star, to help along with construction to see if there could be some tasks that you may be able to help with. To help frame problems, you will need to start at the beginning of CRISP-DM and get some business understanding from staff. You’ve never worked in multi-teared-galaxy-dominating agency before, so it’s good to talk with others and see where you may be able to help.
“Maybe we could find a way to better automate firing on a planet, so I didn’t have to bear the incredible guilt and disgust I feel about doing this”

Wow. That’s rough. Is there ways to further automate the firing of a massive planet destroying super laser? Potentially, but as launching directive comes from a simple human directive, I think having the additional level of manual oversight is probably intentional. Just because some things can be automated doesn’t mean they need to be, and ensuring the proper execution of planet destroying orders could use a personal approach. Any changes to the computational process would most likely be more a pure engineering improvement. Maybe changed departments?
“I think we might have a Rebel spy who is sending our plans out. What can you do?”

That sounds like a pretty serious problem! We probably also have an existing data source to work with with: the logs of communications. Since we’re The Empire and there’s no secrets around here, we can gather as much data as we can on all outgoing communications from the base. We need to first get a sense of this comms data, maybe see if we find anything irregular, like staff sending messages when scheduled on duty, messages sent during odd hours, anything that includes a schematic attachment, or anything sent to known enemies (a rebelalliance.org email is a common tip-off). If we still aren’t finding enough, we could do more evaluation of the actual text, either just by searching for particular key words or phrases, or even sentiment to look for discouraged staff. If we want to monitor future messages, we can look to building a model that searches for the particular criteria (based on what we found in research) and have it alert us when potential offenders appear!
“I need to make sure we aren’t letting people slip through our shields with older clearance codes. My neck is on the line, hahaha, but seriously it is. I’ve seen it.”

Yeah, I’ve heard that might be an issue. I’m going to assume because you flippantly allow older codes that there is no formal system of managing them, beyond some handwritten post-it notes. This might not be at a point where we can do good analysis, but we can look into creating some organization for code management to begin with, perhaps by organizing a new database. We can work as a team, along with engineering, to understand how the codes should be organized and come up with an appropriate system. We can create reporting on code use and keep everyone up to date on what is acceptable. If we get to a point with enough understanding of code use, we could look into some other solutions that could automate the process, but sounds like we have some lengthy ground work ahead.
“I’m concerned about Jedi coming on board and seriously compromising our security systems.”

You can have all the Stormtroopers you want, but if they fall to Jedi mind tricks, what’s the point!? Maintaining base safety is definitely a key priority, and I think we may have some options. Perhaps with some cameras we can use facial recognition to watch out for pesky Jedi. If we gather some images of any known Jedi, we can train a model to look for the exact person and warn us if they are on the station. As just an example, let’s take that Obi-Wan Kenobi character and train it on him, since I’m pretty sure he’s all that is left. Here’s an example of what we might find if he shows up:
This will take us some time, and computing power, but I think this ones possible.
“I’d like a system to automate delivering critical updates to upper management without getting killed”

I’m sorry, Ozzel. Dealing with others, especially those with supernatural choking abilities, is part of the job. Communication, especially within a team, is not something that can be automated away. We can discuss more how your team communicates and see if there are systems that can be set into place to make updates are more transparent, but you will have to handle working with others. If you are feeling intimidated, I suggest talking with HR, but I don’t have a good feeling they can help you either.
“I want to systematically destroy all those who rebel against the Empire so I can stop killing for just five minutes and sit with the emotional impact of what has happened in my life.”

It is understandably frustrating that this rebelling thing is so regular. I don’t think there is a magic bullet for finding all the Rebel Alliance, but we can look for trends in information to see if we can help narrow down where to find them. We can review data about past Rebel bases, find out as much detail about the locations (climate, solar system, distance from previous base, etc.) and resources (how many Rebels were there, type of firepower, etc. ) at each, and see if we can find any trends that could be helpful. If it looks like we can find a clear enough pattern, we may be able to take our research further into creating a model that, based on the most recent found base, can approximate where they might go next.
As you can see, data science solutions aren’t for everything, but when possible, you can do some amazing work that can improve how an organization runs.
Your home for data science. A Medium publication sharing concepts, ideas and codes.
